title-group.article-title: Effect of gastric distension with concurrent small intestinal saline or glucose infusion on incretin hormone secretion in healthy individuals: A randomized, controlled, crossover study

aff.institution: Centre of Research Excellence in Translating Nutritional Science to Good Health

author-notes.corresp: *Correspondence Karen L. Jones, PhD, Adelaide Medical School, The University of Adelaide, Adelaide Health and Medical Sciences Building, North Terrace, Adelaide, South Australia 5005, Australia. Email: karen.jones@adelaide.edu.au

permissions.copyright-statement: ¬© 2023 The Authors. Diabetes, Obesity and Metabolism published by John Wiley & Sons Ltd.

license.license-p: This is an open access article under the terms of the http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/4.0/ License, which permits use, distribution and reproduction in any medium, provided the original work is properly cited.

sec.title: Aim
sec.p: To evaluate the effect of gastric distension, induced using a gastric ‚Äòbarostat‚Äô, on the secretion of glucose‚Äêdependent insulinotropic polypeptide (GIP) and glucagon‚Äêlike peptide‚Äê1 (GLP‚Äê1) in the presence and absence of small intestinal nutrients in healthy individuals.

sec.title: Materials and Methods
sec.p: Eight healthy participants (two females, six males, mean age 69.3‚Äâ¬±‚Äâ1.2‚Äâyears, body mass index 23.5‚Äâ¬±‚Äâ0.8‚Äâkg/m2) were each studied on four occasions when they received an intraduodenal infusion of either (i) 0.9% saline or (ii) glucose delivered at a rate of 3‚Äâkcal/min both with, and without, an intragastric balloon with the pressure set to 8‚ÄâmmHg above the intragastric minimum distending pressure.

sec.title: Results
sec.p: Following intraduodenal saline or glucose infusion, there was no difference in plasma GLP‚Äê1 with or without gastric distension (P¬†=¬†1.00 for both saline and glucose infusions). There was also no difference in plasma GIP with or without gastric distension (P¬†=¬†1.00 for saline infusion and P¬†=¬†.99 for glucose infusion).

sec.title: Conclusions
sec.p: Gastric distension, either alone or during small intestinal glucose exposure, does not stimulate incretin hormone secretion significantly in healthy humans.

institution-wrap.institution: National Health and Medical Research Council

p.mixed-citation: JallehRJ, TrahairLG, WuT, et al. Effect of gastric distension with concurrent small intestinal saline or glucose infusion on incretin hormone secretion in healthy individuals: A randomized, controlled, crossover study. Diabetes Obes Metab. 2023;25(7):1849‚Äê1854. doi:10.1111/dom.15042 36864654

sec.title: INTRODUCTION
sec.p: The use of intragastric balloons as a therapy for obesity was initially explored in the mid‚Äê1980s, but following the negative outcome of a sham‚Äêcontrolled trial and evidence of substantial complications, it was not evaluated further.1 Decades later, interest in this therapy for obesity has re‚Äêemerged.2, 3 Newer balloon designs are safer,2, 3 and may be ‚Äòprocedureless‚Äô (i.e. swallowable)2 or adjustable,3 while the reversibility of this therapy is an advantage over metabolic surgery. Furthermore, the use of an intragastric balloon may also be an effective ‚Äòbridging therapy‚Äô for people with obesity when urgent weight reduction is indicated to reduce operative risk.4 However, the fundamental question of how gastric distension induces weight loss remains unknown. Increased secretion of incretin hormones, in particular glucagon‚Äêlike peptide‚Äê1 (GLP‚Äê1), is believed to be a key mediator for weight loss and remission of type 2 diabetes following metabolic surgery, and represents a potential mechanism for the effectiveness of intragastric balloons.5, 6 The concept that non‚Äênutrient gastric distension could stimulate GLP‚Äê1 has recently been shown in rodent studies. Natochin et al.7 reported that intragastric administration of water and sodium chloride stimulated plasma GLP‚Äê1 markedly within 15‚Äâminutes, as did gastric balloon distension in anaesthetised rats. In unanesthetized mice, Ohbayashi et al.8 reported that gastric distension with a pectin‚Äêcontaining carbonated solution resulted in a load‚Äêdependent, sustained, substantial stimulation of portal concentrations of GLP‚Äê1. It has been suggested that effects on vagal function may underlie the stimulation of GLP‚Äê1. There is no information about the effect of gastric distension on the secretion of the other incretin hormone, glucose‚Äêdependent insulinotropic polypeptide (GIP), in animals.

In contrast to the robust evidence of a major effect of gastric distension on GLP‚Äê1 secretion in rodents, it is not known whether gastric distension affects either GLP‚Äê1 and/or GIP secretion in humans. That Steinert et al.9 observed that intragastric infusion of glucose stimulated plasma GLP‚Äê1 more than an equivalent amount of intraduodenally infused glucose in healthy individuals, suggests that gastric signalling may potentiate nutrient‚Äêinduced GLP‚Äê1 secretion.

As incretin hormones, GIP and GLP‚Äê1 have a major role in postprandial glucose homeostasis.10 GIP is secreted predominantly by K‚Äêcells in the proximal small intestine and GLP‚Äê1 by L‚Äêcells in the distal small intestine and colon.11 GIP and GLP‚Äê1 are released in response to all three macronutrients12 following nutrient entry into the small intestine and subsequent digestion, and the stimulation of GLP‚Äê1 in turn inhibits subsequent gastric emptying,13 suppresses appetite and reduces energy intake.14 In contrast to GLP‚Äê1, GIP neither slows gastric emptying15 nor appears to reduce energy intake in humans14; however, a co‚Äêagonist of both GLP‚Äê1 and GIP, tirzepatide, has recently been shown to promote greater weight loss than GLP‚Äê1 mono‚Äêagonists.16 Accordingly, stimulation of incretin hormones, perhaps particularly GLP‚Äê1, represents an important mechanism for inducing weight loss. Nutrient preloads of glucose, protein or fat stimulate the secretion of endogenous incretins, but at the cost of additional energy intake.17, 18, 19 A non‚Äênutritive strategy to enhance incretin secretion would be highly desirable.

The purpose of this study was to evaluate the effects of gastric distension, using a gastric barostat, on the secretion of GIP and GLP‚Äê1 in the presence and absence of small intestinal nutrients in healthy individuals. While gastric distension may potentially have a different effect on incretin hormones in individuals with obesity, we considered that an understanding of normal physiology represented an appropriate initial step.

sec.title: Participants
sec.p: Eight healthy older participants (two females and six males, mean age 69.3‚Äâ¬±‚Äâ1.2‚Äâyears, body mass index [BMI] 23.5‚Äâ¬±‚Äâ0.8‚Äâkg/m2) were recruited. All participants were non‚Äêsmokers and none had a history of cardiac, respiratory, gastrointestinal (or prior gastrointestinal surgery), hepatic or renal disease. None had a history of diabetes, epilepsy or an intake of more than 20‚Äâg of alcohol per day. No participant took medication known to influence gastrointestinal function. This is a secondary analysis and data from this cohort relating to the effects of gastric distension and small intestinal nutrients on blood pressure and superior mesenteric artery blood flow have been reported.20

sec.title: Protocol
sec.p: Participants were studied on four occasions in a randomized order following an overnight fast (10¬†hours for solids, 8¬†hours for liquids), separated by at least 3‚Äâdays. Upon arrival at the laboratory at the Royal Adelaide Hospital, a silicone‚Äêrubber, multilumen nasoduodenal catheter (Dentsleeve International, Mui Scientific, Mississauga, Canada) was inserted into the stomach via an anaesthetized nostril and allowed to pass into the duodenum by peristalsis. The catheter comprised an infusion channel (internal diameter‚Äâ~‚Äâ1‚Äâmm) located ~‚Äâ10‚Äâcm distal to the pylorus with two other channels, located 2.5‚Äâcm either side of the pylorus, perfused continuously with 0.9% saline, allowing continuous measurement of the transmucosal potential difference from the antral (‚àí40‚ÄâmV) and duodenal (0‚ÄâmV) channels to ensure correct positioning of the catheter.21, 22 An intravenous cannula was positioned in the antecubital fossa of one arm for blood sampling.

On two of the four study days, the participant also swallowed a single‚Äêlumen polyvinyl orogastric catheter (external diameter‚Äâ~‚Äâ4‚Äâmm) (Tygon tubing, Saint Gobain Performance Plastics, Akron, OH) equipped with a thin, flaccid polyethylene bag (capacity 1200‚Äâml) that was tightly wrapped around the distal end. The proximal end of the catheter was connected to a gastric barostat (Distender Series II, G&J Electronics, Willowdale, ON, Canada). The barostat bag was inflated by 1‚ÄâmmHg every 5‚Äâminutes to determine the intragastric minimum distending pressure (MDP), which represents the minimum pressure required to overcome the intra‚Äêabdominal pressure and is defined as the pressure to achieve a volume of more than‚Äâ30‚Äâml in the bag.20, 23 The stomach was then distended using a stepwise increase in intragastric pressure by 2‚ÄêmmHg increments every 3‚Äâminutes, in four steps, to achieve a distension of 8‚ÄâmmHg above MDP.24 Between t¬†=¬†0‚Äê60‚Äâminutes, subjects received an intraduodenal infusion of either (a) 0.9% saline, (b) 25% glucose at 3‚Äâkcal/min, (c) 0.9% saline with intrabag pressure set to 8‚ÄâmmHg above MDP or (d) glucose at 3‚Äâkcal/min with intrabag pressure set to 8‚ÄâmmHg above MDP in a computer‚Äêgenerated randomized order. At this rate of glucose infusion, there would be substantial stimulation of incretin hormones.25 Participants and investigators were blinded to whether saline or glucose was infused. At t¬†=¬†60‚Äâminutes the barostat bag was deflated and between t¬†=¬†60‚Äê120‚Äâminutes 0.9% saline was infused intraduodenally.20, 22 Intraduodenal infusions were performed at a rate of 3‚Äâml/min.

sec.title: Data collection
sec.p: Venous blood samples (~‚Äâ18‚Äâml) were obtained at 15‚Äêminute intervals between t¬†=¬†0‚Äê120‚Äâminutes. Blood samples were centrifuged at 3200‚Äârpm for 15‚Äâminutes and plasma or serum was separated and stored at ‚àí70¬∞C for subsequent analysis.

sec.title: Ethics
sec.p: The protocol was approved by the Research Ethics Committee of the Royal Adelaide Hospital, and was performed in accordance with the Declaration of Helsinki. Each subject provided written, informed consent.

sec.title: Blood glucose
sec.p: Blood glucose concentrations (mmol/L) were determined immediately using a portable blood glucose meter (Precision QID System, Abbott Laboratories, Medisense Products, Bedford, MA).

sec.title: Glucagon‚Äêlike peptide‚Äê1
sec.p: Plasma total GLP‚Äê1 (pmol/L) was measured by radioimmunoassay (GLPIT‚Äê36HK, Millipore, Billerica, MA). The minimum detectable limit was 3‚Äâpmol/L, and the intra‚Äêassay and inter‚Äêassay coefficients‚Äâof variation (CVs) were 4.2% and 10.5%, respectively.26

sec.title: Glucose‚Äêdependent insulinotropic polypeptide
sec.p: Plasma total GIP (pmol/L) was measured by radioimmunoassay with modifications of a published method.27 The minimum detectable limit was 2‚Äâpmol/L, and the intra‚Äêassay and inter‚Äêassay CVs were 6.1% and 15.4%, respectively.26

sec.title: Statistical analysis
sec.p: The area under the curve (AUC) was calculated for all variables using the trapezoidal rule. Basal values and AUCs were compared using one‚Äêfactor repeated‚Äêmeasures analysis of variance (ANOVA). Variables were also analysed using two‚Äêfactor repeated measures ANOVA, with treatment and time as factors. Where significance was revealed by ANOVAs, post hoc comparisons adjusted by Bonferroni‚ÄìHolm's correction, were performed. All analyses were performed using SPSS 17.0.0 (SPSS Inc, Chicago, IL). Data are presented as mean values‚Äâ¬±‚ÄâSEM. A P value of less than .05 was considered significant.

sec.title: RESULTS
sec.p: The studies were well tolerated and completed by all participants. There were no differences in baseline concentrations of blood glucose (P¬†=¬†.78), plasma GIP (P¬†=¬†.59) or plasma GLP‚Äê1 (P¬†=¬†.98) between the four study days.

sec.title: Blood glucose
sec.p: There was a predictable increase in blood glucose during glucose and glucose‚Äâ+‚Äâdistension (P‚Äâ<‚Äâ.001 for both), and no change during either saline or saline‚Äâ+‚Äâdistension (P¬†=¬†.55 and P¬†=¬†.48, respectively). There was a treatment effect (P‚Äâ<‚Äâ.001) for the AUC for blood glucose, so that blood glucose was greater during glucose compared with saline (P‚Äâ<‚Äâ.001) and saline‚Äâ+‚Äâdistension (P‚Äâ<‚Äâ.001), and greater during glucose‚Äâ+‚Äâdistension compared with saline (P‚Äâ<‚Äâ.005) and saline‚Äâ+‚Äâdistension (P‚Äâ<‚Äâ.005), with no difference between glucose and glucose‚Äâ+‚Äâdistension (P¬†=¬†1.00) or between saline and saline‚Äâ+‚Äâdistension (P¬†=¬†1.00) (Figure¬†1A).

caption.p: Effects of intraduodenal saline (‚óè, ‚óã) and glucose at 3‚Äâkcal/min (‚ñ†, ‚ñ°) with (‚óã, ‚ñ°) and without (‚óè, ‚ñ†) gastric distension achieved by a barostat set at 8‚ÄâmmHg above minimum distending pressure on A, Blood glucose, B, Plasma glucose‚Äêdependent insulinotropic polypeptide (GIP), and C, Glucagon‚Äêlike peptide‚Äê1 (GLP‚Äê1) in eight healthy participants. Data are mean‚Äâ¬±‚Äâstandard error

sec.title: Glucose‚Äêdependent insulinotropic polypeptide
sec.p: There was a prompt and sustained increase in GIP during glucose and glucose‚Äâ+‚Äâdistension (P‚Äâ<‚Äâ.001 for both), and no change during saline and saline‚Äâ+‚Äâdistension (P¬†=¬†.59 and P¬†=¬†.18, respectively). There was a treatment effect (P‚Äâ<‚Äâ.001) for the AUC for GIP, so that GIP was greater during glucose compared with saline (P‚Äâ<‚Äâ.001) and saline‚Äâ+‚Äâdistension (P‚Äâ<‚Äâ.001), and greater during glucose‚Äâ+‚Äâdistension compared with saline (P‚Äâ<‚Äâ.005) and saline‚Äâ+‚Äâdistension (P‚Äâ<‚Äâ.005), with no difference between glucose and glucose‚Äâ+‚Äâdistension (P¬†=¬†.99) or between saline and saline‚Äâ+‚Äâdistension (P¬†=¬†1.00) (Figure¬†1B).

sec.title: Glucagon‚Äêlike peptide‚Äê1
sec.p: There was a gradual and sustained increase in GLP‚Äê1 during glucose and glucose‚Äâ+‚Äâdistension (P‚Äâ<‚Äâ.001 and P‚Äâ<‚Äâ.05, respectively), and no change during saline and saline with distension (P¬†=¬†.67 and P¬†=¬†.25, respectively). There was a treatment effect (P‚Äâ<‚Äâ.001) for the AUC for GLP‚Äê1, so that GLP‚Äê1 was greater during glucose compared with saline (P‚Äâ<‚Äâ.001) and saline‚Äâ+‚Äâdistension (P‚Äâ<‚Äâ.005), but not glucose‚Äâ+‚Äâdistension (P¬†=¬†1.00). There was no difference between saline and saline‚Äâ+‚Äâdistension (P¬†=¬†1.00) or between glucose‚Äâ+‚Äâdistension and saline‚Äâ+‚Äâdistension (P¬†=¬†.12) (Figure¬†1C and Table 1).

caption.p: Total area under the curve (tAUC) from 0 to 60‚Äâminutes for glucose (mmol/L‚Äâx‚Äâmin), glucose‚Äêdependent insulinotropic polypeptide (GIP) (pmol/L‚Äâx‚Äâmin) and glucagon‚Äêlike peptide‚Äê1 (GLP‚Äê1) (pmol/L‚Äâx‚Äâmin) following intraduodenal (ID) saline, glucose, saline with balloon distension and glucose with balloon distension (n¬†=¬†8). Data are mean values‚Äâ¬±‚ÄâSEM

sec.title: Intrabag volumes
sec.p: At baseline, the intrabag volume was 443‚Äâ¬±‚Äâ80‚Äâml during glucose‚Äâ+‚Äâdistension and 410‚Äâ¬±‚Äâ80‚Äâml for saline‚Äâ+‚Äâdistension and, at 60‚Äâminutes, the intrabag volume was 790‚Äâ¬±‚Äâ71‚Äâml for glucose‚Äâ+‚Äâdistension and 637‚Äâ¬± 80‚Äâml for saline‚Äâ+‚Äâdistension.

sec.title: DISCUSSION
sec.p: Our study indicates that, unlike rodents,7, 8 gastric distension, with or without small intestinal glucose exposure, does not appear to be a stimulus for either GIP or GLP‚Äê1 secretion in humans. The study was conducted under carefully controlled experimental settings to determine whether there was an effect of gastric distension on GIP or GLP‚Äê1 secretion. Intraduodenal infusion of glucose or saline was used to avoid the confounding effect of variable gastric emptying,28 and glucose was administered at a rate that mimics that of gastric emptying29 and is known to elicit substantial GLP‚Äê1 and GIP responses.25 It is, accordingly, unlikely that our observations would have been modified with a higher rate of nutrient delivery. Our study used the barostat technique, a method accepted as the ‚Äògold standard‚Äô for controlled gastric distension,30 and yielded distension volumes of ~‚Äâ700‚Äâml at the given pressure, which was associated with a sensation of fullness.31 For comparison, intragastric balloons with volumes of 550‚Äâml are effective for inducing weight loss,32 and for adjustable intragastric balloons, volumes are initiated at 400‚Äê550‚Äâml and do not exceed 850‚Äâml.3 It should be appreciated that the air‚Äêfilled barostat balloon distends predominantly the proximal, rather than the distal, stomach. Distension of the antrum may be of particular importance in satiation33 and intragastric balloons positioned in the antrum have been associated with greater weight loss.34 However, traditionally, intragastric balloons have been inserted proximally in the fundus,35, 36 although they may migrate to the antrum.34

The reason(s) for the apparent discrepancy in the effect of gastric distension on GLP‚Äê1 secretion between rodents and humans is uncertain. In response to nutrients, the effect of GLP‚Äê1 to increase insulin secretion is evident in both rodents37 and humans.38 Similarly, GIP has been considered to have a major insulinotropic effect in rodents,39 a concept recently consolidated by studies using antagonists to GIP (GIP3‚àí30NH2) in humans.40 A notable difference between rodent and human incretin physiology is that nutrient‚Äêstimulated GLP‚Äê1 secretion is reduced in rodents following subdiaphragmatic vagotomy, while direct vagal stimulation increases GLP‚Äê1 secretion,41 indicating that GLP‚Äê1 secretion in rodents is modulated by the vagus nerve. By contrast, humans who have had a truncal vagotomy with pyloroplasty display an increase, rather than a decrease, in nutrient‚Äêstimulated GLP‚Äê1 and GIP secretion, although more rapid gastric emptying as a consequence of the pyloroplasty may well represent a confounder.42
Future studies investigating the effect of gastric distension on incretin hormone secretion in individuals with obesity and/or type 2 diabetes would be of interest.

sec.title: Limitations
sec.p: Our proof‚Äêof‚Äêconcept pilot study had a small sample size, in part because of its technical complexity, and may be underpowered to identify small differences in the effect of gastric distension on GLP‚Äê1 or GIP secretion. Our healthy participants were older (i.e. aged >‚Äâ65‚Äâyears), but any reductions in incretin hormone secretion with age are modest, and the stimulation of both GLP‚Äê1 and GIP by intraduodenal glucose remained substantial.43 We also cannot exclude the possibility that exposure of the stomach to nutrients (i.e. nutritive distension) in the course of normal meal ingestion may influence incretin secretion.9
In conclusion, in healthy, older adults, gastric distension did not stimulate GIP or GLP‚Äê1 secretion either in the absence or presence of small intestinal nutrient exposure.

sec.title: AUTHOR CONTRIBUTIONS
sec.p: RJJ and LGT were involved in the literature review, data processing, data analysis and interpretation. TW was involved in the study design, data analysis and interpretation. SS was involved in the study methodology and data processing. CF‚ÄêB, CKR and MH were involved in data analysis and interpretation. KLJ was involved in the study design, conduct, literature review, data analysis and interpretation. All the authors contributed to critical review of the manuscript.

sec.title: CONFLICT OF INTEREST
sec.p: The authors report no conflicts of interest. TW has been supported by a Mid‚ÄêCareer Fellowship from The Hospital Research Foundation.

sec.title: PEER REVIEW
sec.p: The peer review history for this article is available at https://www.webofscience.com/api/gateway/wos/peer-review/10.1111/dom.15042.

sec.title: DATA AVAILABILITY STATEMENT
sec.p: The data that support the findings of this study are available from the corresponding author upon reasonable request.
